text: 14 million people are told they have
cancer each year but that figure is
expected to soar to 24 million by 2035
the WA chose international agency for
research on cancer described it as an
oncoming tidal wave caused by people
living longer and the growing global
population it warned that the cost of
treatments were spiraling out of control
and that cancer was not a problem we
could cure our way out of first of all
that we're seeing a very rapid increase
in the numbers of cancers worldwide but
particularly in the lower middle-income
countries so this shows us that cancer
is truly a global problem and that we're
not going to be able to address this
problem by simply improving the
treatment of the disease the second big
change I think is the advance we've seen
in the understanding of the biology of
cancer and now our challenge is to
translate this new knowledge about the
biology into better treatments but also
in two ways to prevent the disease and
detect it early the wh 0 said
governments needed to consider tougher
controls to curb drinking and obesity
such as higher prices for alcohol and
sugar projections show cancer will
become an increasing burden in the
developing world where prevention early
diagnosis and treatments are major
problems the wh 0 said simple measures
could make a difference such as wider
use of the HPV vaccine to prevent
cervical cancer James gallaher BBC News
